Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my mother’s voice echoing in my mind as she explained how important it was for me to lead the family ceremony this year. “It’s your turn to carry on our tradition,” she said, her eyes full of hope and pride. I knew how much this meant to her, to all of us, really. The pressure to do everything perfectly, to honor our family’s values, weighed heavily on my shoulders.

Just as I was rehearsing the ceremonial lines, my phone buzzed. It was Priya, an acquaintance from work. “Hey, I’m in your neighborhood and need a good restaurant recommendation. Can you help?” she texted. I knew she was counting on me; she’d mentioned before how much she trusted my taste. I felt torn—my family expected me to focus on the ceremony, to be present and dedicated, but Priya needed my help right now. My mind raced, caught between the duty to my family and the desire to be a supportive friend. I stared at my phone, heart pounding, unsure which expectation to meet first.
